metadata.description: The data includes the county-level data of characteristic agriculture distribution in the Qinghai Tibet Plateau, which lays the foundation for the spatial distribution and development of characteristic agriculture in the Qinghai Tibet Plateau. The data are from the development plan of Tibet Plateau characteristic agricultural products base (2015-2020), Qinghai province's 13th five year plan, Sichuan Province's 13th five year plan for agricultural and rural economic development, Xinjiang Uygur Autonomous Region's 13th five year plan for targeted poverty alleviation of agricultural characteristic industries (2016-2020), Yunnan Province's overall plan for plateau characteristic agricultural modernization（ 2016-2020), implementation opinions on fostering and strengthening characteristic agricultural industries in Gansu Province to boost poverty alleviation, China National Geographic Indication product network (http://www.cgi.gov.cn/home/default/), regional layout planning of characteristic agricultural products (2013-2020). The data is the distribution of county-level characteristic agriculture, realizing the spatialization of county-level characteristic agriculture. The data can be applied to the research on the spatial distribution of characteristic agriculture and the development of characteristic agriculture in the future.
metadata.instructions: The data of special agricultural spatial layout is stored in text format, and the file name is qzgytytype.xlsx. The data includes four worksheets, including highland barley, yak, sheep and wolfberry. Name is the name of the county, ID is the number of each county in the Qinghai Tibet Plateau during the statistics. Type1, type2, type3 and type4 are the characteristic agricultural types of each county.

background: Tree cover, defined structurally as the proportional, vertically projected area of vegetation (including leaves, stems, branches, etc.) of woody plants above a given height, affects terrestrial energy and water exchanges, photosynthesis and transpiration, net primary production, and carbon and nutrient fluxes. Tree cover also affects habitat quality and movements of wildlife, residential property value for humans, and numerous other ecosystem services. Importantly for monitoring, reporting, and verification (MRV) efforts to reduce carbon dioxide emissions from deforestation and forest degradation and to foster conservation and sustainable management of forests (REDD), tree cover provides a measurable attribute upon which forest cover may be defined. Further, changes in tree cover over time can be used to monitor and retrieve site-specific histories of forest disturbance, succession, and degradation.
research objective: We produced a global, 30-m resolution tree cover dataset for circa-2000 and 2005 epochs by rescaling the 250-m MODIS VCF Tree Cover dataset using Landsat images and ancillary data. To serve as a baseline of comparison and to help fill the dearth of error assessments of the MODIS VCF, we also performed a parallel accuracy assessment of the MODIS VCF against lidar measurements.
challenges: The spatial and thematic scale of the MODIS VCF and other continuous-field datasets (e.g. Asner et al. 2009) have made reference data difficult to acquire and so quantitative error estimates of these datasets are quite limited. Across all biomes and types of reference data, these independent assessments found that saturation of the optical signal, phenological noise, and confusion with dense herbaceous vegetation led to errors in the MODIS VCF between 10/C131% Root-Mean-Square Error (RMSE), over-estimation in areas of low cover, and under-estimation in areas of high cover.
methods: We developed a global, 30-m resolution dataset of percent tree cover by rescaling the 250-m Moderate-resolution Imaging Spectroradiometer (MODIS) Vegetation Continuous Fields (VCF) Tree Cover layer using circa-2000 and 2005 Landsat images, incorporating the MODIS Cropland Layer to improve accuracy in agricultural areas.
dataset: We produced a global, 30-m resolution tree cover dataset for circa-2000 and 2005 epochs by rescaling the 250-m MODIS VCF Tree Cover dataset using Landsat images and ancillary data.
findings: Resulting Landsat-based estimates maintained consistency with the MODIS VCF in both epochs (RMSE/C308.6% in 2000 and 11.9% in 2005), but showed improved accuracy in agricultural areas and increased discrimination of small forest patches. Against lidar measurements, the Landsat-based estimates exhibited accuracy slightly less than that of the MODIS VCF (RMSE/C3016.8% for MODIS-based vs. 17.4% for Landsat-based estimates), but RMSE of Landsat estimates was 3.3 percentage points lower than that of the MODIS data in an agricultural region. The Landsat data retained the saturation artifact of the MODIS VCF at greater than or equal to 80% tree cover but showed greater potential for removal of errors through calibration to lidar, with post-calibration RMSE of 9.4% compared to 13.5% in MODIS estimates.

Definition.Question: What is the meaning of 'forest canopy cover data' in the context of remote sensing and forest monitoring?
Definition.Answer: Forest canopy cover data refers to the percentage of ground area covered by the vertical projection of tree canopies, which includes vegetation such as leaves, stems, and branches of woody plants above a certain height. It is crucial for understanding energy and water exchanges, photosynthesis, carbon fluxes, and ecosystem services, and serves as a measurable attribute for monitoring forest cover changes over time.

Comparison.Question: How does the method of rescaling the 250-m MODIS VCF Tree Cover dataset using Landsat images compare to the use of lidar measurements for accuracy assessment?
Comparison.Answer: Rescaling the MODIS VCF Tree Cover dataset using Landsat images aims to improve accuracy, especially in agricultural areas, while lidar measurements provide a benchmark for accuracy assessment. The Landsat-based estimates showed improved discrimination of small forest patches and greater potential for error removal through calibration, although the accuracy was slightly less than that of the MODIS VCF when compared to lidar measurements.

Comparison.Question: What are the challenges faced by the MODIS VCF dataset in terms of spatial and thematic scale, and how do these compare to the challenges experienced during the rescaling process using Landsat images?
Comparison.Answer: The MODIS VCF dataset faces challenges such as saturation of optical signals, phenological noise, and confusion with dense herbaceous vegetation, leading to errors in tree cover estimation. In contrast, the rescaling process using Landsat images maintains consistency with MODIS VCF but addresses these challenges by improving accuracy in agricultural areas and increasing discrimination of small forest patches, though it still retains some saturation artifacts.

Interpretation.Question: How might rescaling a 250-m resolution dataset to a 30-m resolution dataset influence the accuracy and applicability of tree cover data in diverse ecological regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Rescaling a 250-m resolution dataset to a 30-m resolution using Landsat images can improve accuracy, particularly in agricultural areas and in distinguishing small forest patches. However, challenges such as saturation of optical signals and phenological noise may still persist, requiring careful calibration to lidar data to further reduce errors.

Interpretation.Question: What are the potential challenges in acquiring reference data for continuous-field datasets, and how do these challenges affect the error estimation process?
Interpretation.Answer: Challenges in acquiring reference data for continuous-field datasets include the spatial and thematic scale which makes quantitative error estimates limited. Factors such as saturation of optical signals, phenological noise, and confusion with dense herbaceous vegetation contribute to errors, leading to overestimation in areas of low cover and underestimation in areas of high cover.

Interpretation.Question: How can integrating ancillary data, such as the MODIS Cropland Layer, enhance the accuracy of forest cover datasets, particularly in agricultural regions?
Interpretation.Answer: Integrating ancillary data like the MODIS Cropland Layer can enhance the accuracy of forest cover datasets by improving discrimination of tree cover in agricultural areas, where traditional methods may overestimate or underestimate coverage. This integration helps refine the dataset's applicability and reduce root-mean-square errors in these regions.

Causal Antecedent.Question: What factors contribute to the difficulty in acquiring reference data for continuous-field datasets like MODIS VCF, and how do these challenges affect the accuracy assessment of such datasets?
Causal Antecedent.Answer: The spatial and thematic scale of MODIS VCF and similar datasets make reference data difficult to acquire, limiting quantitative error estimates. Saturation of optical signals, phenological noise, and confusion with dense herbaceous vegetation lead to errors, including over-estimation in areas of low cover and under-estimation in areas of high cover.

Causal Consequence.Question: What are the potential consequences of rescaling a 250-m resolution dataset to a 30-m resolution for tree cover estimation?
Causal Consequence.Answer: Rescaling a 250-m resolution dataset to a 30-m resolution for tree cover estimation can improve accuracy in certain areas, such as agricultural regions, and increase the discrimination of small forest patches. However, it may still retain certain artifacts, such as saturation at high tree cover percentages.

Causal Consequence.Question: How does the inclusion of ancillary data, such as the MODIS Cropland Layer, impact the accuracy of tree cover datasets?
Causal Consequence.Answer: The inclusion of ancillary data like the MODIS Cropland Layer can enhance the accuracy of tree cover datasets, particularly in agricultural areas, as it helps to better differentiate between cropland and forested regions.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the primary objective of developing a global, 30-m resolution tree cover dataset using Landsat images?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The primary objective is to produce a dataset that serves as a baseline for comparison and to fill the dearth of error assessments of the MODIS VCF by providing more accurate tree cover estimates, especially in agricultural areas, and to improve the discrimination of small forest patches.

Goal Orientation.Question: Why is it important to perform a parallel accuracy assessment of the MODIS VCF against lidar measurements?
Goal Orientation.Answer: It is important to perform this assessment to address the challenges posed by the spatial and thematic scale of the MODIS VCF, which makes reference data difficult to acquire and results in limited quantitative error estimates. This assessment helps identify and correct errors due to saturation of the optical signal, phenological noise, and confusion with dense herbaceous vegetation.

Goal Orientation.Question: What is the intended benefit of using the MODIS Cropland Layer in the rescaling of the MODIS VCF Tree Cover dataset with Landsat images?
Goal Orientation.Answer: The intended benefit of using the MODIS Cropland Layer is to improve the accuracy of the tree cover estimates in agricultural areas, thereby enhancing the overall reliability of the dataset compared to the original MODIS VCF data.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: What procedural steps are necessary to rescale a MODIS Vegetation Continuous Fields Tree Cover dataset using Landsat images to achieve a 30-m resolution tree cover dataset?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: To rescale a MODIS Vegetation Continuous Fields Tree Cover dataset using Landsat images, one must first acquire circa-2000 and 2005 Landsat images and ancillary data. The process involves rescaling the 250-m resolution MODIS VCF Tree Cover dataset to a finer 30-m resolution using these images. Incorporating the MODIS Cropland Layer is also crucial to improve accuracy specifically in agricultural areas.

Instrumental/Procedural.Question: How can errors in tree cover estimates due to saturation of the optical signal and phenological noise be addressed during dataset refinement?
Instrumental/Procedural.Answer: Errors such as saturation of the optical signal and phenological noise in tree cover estimates can be addressed by calibrating the dataset against lidar measurements. This calibration process helps in removing errors and reducing the Root-Mean-Square Error (RMSE). For example, post-calibration, the RMSE for Landsat data was reduced to 9.4% compared to 13.5% in MODIS estimates.

Enablement.Question: What techniques enable the rescaling of a lower-resolution vegetation dataset to a higher resolution for improved accuracy in forest cover assessment?
Enablement.Answer: The rescaling of a lower-resolution vegetation dataset to a higher resolution is enabled by using Landsat images and ancillary data. The process involves rescaling the 250-m MODIS VCF Tree Cover dataset using circa-2000 and 2005 Landsat images, which helps enhance accuracy in agricultural areas and improves discrimination of small forest patches.

Enablement.Question: How do technological advancements in satellite imaging support the development of high-resolution tree cover datasets?
Enablement.Answer: Technological advancements in satellite imaging support the development of high-resolution tree cover datasets by utilizing the Landsat-5 and Landsat-7 sensors, which provide seven bands of data. These advancements allow for the compilation of global land surveys and accurate rescaling of existing datasets to 30-m resolution, thus enabling better monitoring and verification of tree cover changes.

Enablement.Question: What methods allow for the reduction of errors in tree cover datasets, especially in regions with dense vegetation?
Enablement.Answer: Errors in tree cover datasets, especially in regions with dense vegetation, can be reduced through calibration with lidar measurements. This method helps address the saturation artifact present in optical signals of high tree cover areas. By calibrating the Landsat-based estimates to lidar data, the post-calibration Root-Mean-Square Error (RMSE) can be improved, reducing inaccuracies in the datasets.

Expectation.Question: Why might there be inaccuracies in estimating tree cover percentages using remote sensing data, and what factors could contribute to these errors?
Expectation.Answer: Inaccuracies in estimating tree cover percentages can arise due to the saturation of optical signals, phenological noise, and confusion with dense herbaceous vegetation. These factors can lead to over-estimation in areas of low cover and under-estimation in areas of high cover, as observed with the MODIS VCF datasets.

Expectation.Question: In what ways could incorporating ancillary data into remote sensing analyses enhance the accuracy of forest cover estimations?
Expectation.Answer: Incorporating ancillary data, such as the MODIS Cropland Layer, can improve accuracy in agricultural areas by reducing confusion between tree cover and non-forest vegetation. This approach can lead to better discrimination of small forest patches and help refine the overall accuracy of forest cover estimations.

Judgmental.Question: What is your opinion on the challenges faced in obtaining reference data for continuous-field datasets in forest cover studies?
Judgmental.Answer: The challenges in obtaining reference data for continuous-field datasets in forest cover studies include difficulties in acquiring data at appropriate spatial and thematic scales. The saturation of optical signals, phenological noise, and confusion with dense herbaceous vegetation contribute to errors, making quantitative error estimates quite limited.

Judgmental.Question: How would you evaluate the effectiveness of rescaling MODIS VCF data using Landsat images in improving accuracy for tree cover datasets?
Judgmental.Answer: Rescaling MODIS VCF data using Landsat images has shown effectiveness in improving accuracy for tree cover datasets. Although Landsat-based estimates exhibit slightly less accuracy against lidar measurements than MODIS VCF, they maintain consistency and show improved accuracy in agricultural areas and increased discrimination of small forest patches. Calibration to lidar further reduces errors.

Judgmental.Question: What is your assessment of using a global, 30-m resolution dataset for monitoring forest cover changes over time?
Judgmental.Answer: Using a global, 30-m resolution dataset for monitoring forest cover changes over time is beneficial as it provides a measurable attribute for defining forest cover. It facilitates monitoring site-specific histories of forest disturbance, succession, and degradation while maintaining consistency with existing datasets like MODIS VCF, although calibration may be needed to address saturation artifacts.

Assertion.Question: I don't understand how tree cover data can be accurately measured and adjusted using different satellite imagery techniques.
Assertion.Answer: Tree cover data can be accurately measured and adjusted by rescaling lower resolution datasets, like the 250-m MODIS VCF Tree Cover dataset, using higher resolution Landsat images. This method also involves incorporating other layers, such as the MODIS Cropland Layer, to improve accuracy, especially in agricultural areas.

Assertion.Question: I'm unsure about the challenges faced in acquiring reference data for continuous-field datasets.
Assertion.Answer: The challenges in acquiring reference data for continuous-field datasets include the spatial and thematic scale limitations, which make it difficult to obtain quantitative error estimates. Issues such as the saturation of optical signals, phenological noise, and confusion with dense herbaceous vegetation contribute to errors in datasets like the MODIS VCF.

Assertion.Question: I can't figure out how lidar measurements are used to validate and improve the accuracy of tree cover datasets.
Assertion.Answer: Lidar measurements are used to validate and improve the accuracy of tree cover datasets by providing a benchmark for comparison. For example, Landsat-based estimates maintained consistency with the MODIS VCF but showed greater potential for error removal through calibration to lidar, resulting in a lower post-calibration Root-Mean-Square Error compared to MODIS estimates.

Request/Directive.Question: Please provide an exploration of challenges encountered in acquiring reference data for continuous-field datasets and the implications for error estimation.
Request/Directive.Answer: The spatial and thematic scale of continuous-field datasets like the MODIS VCF has made reference data difficult to acquire, leading to limited quantitative error estimates. Challenges include saturation of the optical signal, phenological noise, and confusion with dense herbaceous vegetation, resulting in errors such as a Root-Mean-Square Error (RMSE) of 10-31%, over-estimation in areas of low cover, and under-estimation in areas of high cover.

Request/Directive.Question: Please outline the methods used to develop a high-resolution tree cover dataset and how these methods address accuracy in specific regions.
Request/Directive.Answer: A global, 30-m resolution tree cover dataset was developed by rescaling the 250-m MODIS Vegetation Continuous Fields (VCF) Tree Cover layer using circa-2000 and 2005 Landsat images. The MODIS Cropland Layer was incorporated to improve accuracy in agricultural areas, resulting in better discrimination of small forest patches and improved accuracy over the MODIS VCF in these regions.

Request/Directive.Question: Please discuss potential strategies for improving the accuracy of tree cover estimates in datasets and their applicability in different biomes.
Request/Directive.Answer: Strategies for improving accuracy include calibrating Landsat-based estimates to lidar measurements, which reduced RMSE from 13.5% in MODIS estimates to 9.4% post-calibration. The Landsat data, while retaining saturation artifacts at greater than or equal to 80% tree cover, showed potential for error removal through such calibration, suggesting applicability for diverse biomes, especially in agricultural regions.
